definitions.definition: a feeling of great worry or unhappiness; great mental pain

examples.text: The newspaper article caused the actor considerable distress.
She sensed his deep emotional distress.
She was obviously in distress after the attack.

definitions.definition: severe problems caused by not having enough money, food, etc.

examples.text: The charity aims to relieve poverty and distress caused by natural disasters.

definitions.definition: a situation in which a ship, plane, etc. is in danger or difficulty and needs help

examples.text: **a distress signal** *(= a message asking for help)*
It is a rule of the sea to help another boat in distress.

definitions.definition: a state of physical pain and effort, especially difficulty in breathing

examples.text: The patient was suffering serious **respiratory distress**.
The baby was clearly in distress.

definitions.definition: a young woman who needs help

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French destresce (noun), destrecier (verb), based on Latin distringere ‘stretch apart’.
